documents.t: Normal paragraph with <breaking syntax> List item 1 is normal List item 2 has <syntax> which causes issues for the html parser (& what about : / \ [ ] { } ; ‚Äú ‚Äò)?! See https://github.com/sillsdev/docu-notion/issues/21 What about a link with <angle brackets>?

This page is special in that it exists in the outline rather than the database where we prefer pages to live. It is here to demonstrate that docu-notion will still retrieve it. This is a raw link to the intro: link_to_page This is a raw link to the fruits section: link_to_page This is a link to Apples. This is a bare to google https://www.google.com/

Docusaurus has some nice custom callouts called ‚ÄúAdmonitions‚Äù. note Note about something tip Tip about something with an internal link. info Info about something caution A Caution about something danger Something dangerous ‚Üê should be bold :::üöß A note about this being under construction :::

If docu-notion notices that you have embed a video it should convert that to code useable in Docusaurus by using react-player. docu-notion does the following when it detects a link to a video: Adds a import ReactPlayer from "react-player"; to the markdown Inserts html like <ReactPlayer controls url="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5M3nJrlf3p0&t=70s" /> info If your site is not based on docu-notion-sample-site, you may need to add ReactPlayer to your Docusaurus project: yarn add react-player or npm i react-player caution docu-notion can‚Äôt yet tell if the link points to video or not, so it currently just looks for patterns indicating youtube or vimeo.
(credit: Pixabay, license: free Pixabay license) Apples are better than oranges. link_to_page
If you embed a gif in notion, it should be embedded in Docusaurus

When it detects an embedded gif, docu-notion does the following: Adds a import GifPlayer from "react-gif-player"; to the markdown. Inserts html like <GifPlayer gif="https://media.giphy.com/media/VhiAuDYHkNPydiNnOs/giphy.gif" /> info If your site is not based on docu-notion-sample-site, you may need to add react-gif-player to your Docusaurus project: yarn add react-gif-player or npm i react-gif-player
one two Some text in between three this is three aa four This is a bulleted list: alpha beta A todo item Another todo item This is a toggle The inside of a toggle This is an empty toggle

docu-notion will convert the url to the bloomlibrary.org book detail or player (READ) page into an embedded book: https://bloomlibrary.org/EFL-education-for-life-org/EFL-TokPlesBooks/EFL-TokPles-Hako/book/x2Y9Q65L90 https://dev-alpha.bloomlibrary.org/player/Z671oJ4TsM You can also use the notion embed feature to get something more WYSIWYG. Here, I have embedded https://dev-alpha.bloomlibrary.org/player/Z671oJ4TsM: embed

docu-notion lets you use Notion as your editor for markdown-based static site generators like Docusaurus. Using Notion instead of raw markdown files means that you don't have to teach non-developers how to make git commits and pull requests. It also allows you to leverage Notion's database tools to control workflow, Notion's commenting feature to discuss changes, etc. tip Note that docu-notion is not a service that could be reading your data. docu-notion is just open-source code that will run on your computer or your CI system. info In Notion, notice that the slug of this page is a slash. This tells Docusaurus that this is the default document to show.
